Given an already built package `/chpcwgg`:
```
$ spack find -dlv /chpcwgg
==> 1 installed packages.
-- linux-ubuntu16-x86_64 / gcc@5.4.0 ----------------------------
chpcwgg    paraview@5.0.0+mpi~opengl2~osmesa~python+qt~tcl

pey6g7a            ^libpng@1.6.27
zn23nl6                ^zlib@1.2.11+pic+shared
zswtuew        ^jpeg@9b
3wt4ges        ^libtiff@4.0.6
f4p6ysd            ^xz@5.2.3
4m6dx6f        ^libxml2@2.9.4~python
2uaqbv4        ^openmpi@2.0.2~java~mxm~pmi~psm~psm2~slurm~sqlite3~thread_multiple~tm~verbs+vt
wapbsf2            ^hwloc@1.11.5
bdodwet                ^libpciaccess@0.13.4
ynzm5xe        ^qt@4.8.6~dbus~examples~gtk~krellpatch~mesa~phonon+webkit
urjozsf            ^fontconfig@2.11.1
no4jtxb                ^font-util@1.3.1
7n2gkck            ^glib@2.49.7
txkub5o                ^gettext@0.19.8.1+bzip2+curses+git~libunistring+libxml2+tar+xz
taazswe                    ^ncurses@6.0~symlinks
zpatvi2                    ^tar@1.29
jtrswbt                ^libffi@3.2.1
vw6umqx                ^pcre@8.39+utf
hhdrcae            ^gperf@3.0.4
fcftpse            ^icu4c@57.1
fre4loq            ^libmng@2.0.2
7kcrn6j                ^lcms@2.6
7mmucce            ^libxcb@1.12
uxq26an                ^libpthread-stubs@0.3
rywz5ym                ^libxau@1.0.8
3tu6t2x                ^libxdmcp@1.1.2
52wmhxm            ^openssl@1.0.2k
```
How do I find out the way it was built? In this example the answer is:
```
spack install paraview +qt ^qt +webkit %gcc@5.4.0
```
I want this so that I can build exactly the same package, but with some modification (perhaps enable Python in paraview, but keep the `qt` built exactly the way it was, and keep the compiler exactly the way it was).

Here is one way, that I am aware of, that does *not* work: you use `spack find` to nail the package, in this case here is how the session could go:
```
$ spack find paraview
==> 2 installed packages.
-- linux-ubuntu16-x86_64 / gcc@5.4.0 ----------------------------
paraview@5.0.0  paraview@5.0.0
$ spack find -dlv paraview
[...]
$ spack find -dlv paraview ^qt+webkit
==> 1 installed packages.
-- linux-ubuntu16-x86_64 / gcc@5.4.0 ----------------------------
chpcwgg    paraview@5.0.0+mpi~opengl2~osmesa~python+qt~tcl
icdmmm2        ^bzip2@1.0.6+shared
d6pxg3p        ^freetype@2.7
pey6g7a            ^libpng@1.6.27
zn23nl6                ^zlib@1.2.11+pic+shared
zswtuew        ^jpeg@9b
3wt4ges        ^libtiff@4.0.6
f4p6ysd            ^xz@5.2.3
4m6dx6f        ^libxml2@2.9.4~python
2uaqbv4        ^openmpi@2.0.2~java~mxm~pmi~psm~psm2~slurm~sqlite3~thread_multiple~tm~verbs+vt
wapbsf2            ^hwloc@1.11.5
bdodwet                ^libpciaccess@0.13.4
ynzm5xe        ^qt@4.8.6~dbus~examples~gtk~krellpatch~mesa~phonon+webkit
urjozsf            ^fontconfig@2.11.1
no4jtxb                ^font-util@1.3.1
7n2gkck            ^glib@2.49.7
txkub5o                ^gettext@0.19.8.1+bzip2+curses+git~libunistring+libxml2+tar+xz
taazswe                    ^ncurses@6.0~symlinks
zpatvi2                    ^tar@1.29
jtrswbt                ^libffi@3.2.1
vw6umqx                ^pcre@8.39+utf
hhdrcae            ^gperf@3.0.4
fcftpse            ^icu4c@57.1
fre4loq            ^libmng@2.0.2
7kcrn6j                ^lcms@2.6
7mmucce            ^libxcb@1.12
uxq26an                ^libpthread-stubs@0.3
rywz5ym                ^libxau@1.0.8
3tu6t2x                ^libxdmcp@1.1.2
52wmhxm            ^openssl@1.0.2k
```
So I nailed it, except that if I try to build it (to check that I really got it):
```
$ spack install paraview ^qt+webkit
==> Error: paraview does not depend on qt
```
I see, I need to do this:
```
$ spack install paraview +qt ^qt+webkit
[...]
```
Oops, it starts building it with the wrong compiler. 


How can I make spack give me the exact spec for the package, that I can then use as a starting point for any modifications?
title: How to find out how a package was built
